thread.title: Ford helps drive Indians past Tigers and ‘elephants’
thread.title_full: Ford helps drive Indians past Tigers and ‘elephants’

title: Ford helps drive Indians past Tigers and ‘elephants’
text:
Ford helps drive Indians past Tigers and ‘elephants’ by Comments 
With Newnan looming next week, East Coweta was in a classic trap game Friday at Douglas County and, early on, things looked iffy for the Indians. 
But the team jumped on the back of fullback Carlos Ford, who piled up 138 yards on 12 carries, two of which ended for scores, and drove to a 42-20 win. 
The win, coupled with Westlake's overtime win against Langston-Hughes, puts the Indians into a four-way tie for first in Region 3- going into next week's rivalry game against Newnan. 
"I felt like they didn't have an answer for Carlos all night," East Coweta coach Steve Pardue said. "We kind of were able to pull away there, and then we let them get a couple. Overall, though, I felt like we had a good night and a win's a win." 
While still not mathematically official, East Coweta has all but clinched a state berth and got a boost from Westlake’s 36-35 overtime win over Hughes in a comeback. 
The Indians are now among four teams tied atop 3- with 4-1 records while holding a head-to-head advantage over Westlake (4-1) and with a chance to do the same against Newnan next week. 
The Indians opened the game with a nine-play drive that was capped off with a 33-yard run by Jeremiah Gemmel to make it 7-0 with 7:12 to play in the first quarter. Douglas County answered quickly with a four-play drive led by Malik Oliver, who finished the drive with an eight-yard touchdown run to tie the game at 7 with 6:13 to go in the opening quarter. 
Douglas County had a chance to take the lead after a partially blocked punt gave them the ball inside Indians' territory, but the Tigers missed a 37-yard field goal. East Coweta took over and took control of the game. The Indians scored in four plays, with Calvin Kirby taking the ball in from 12 yards away to make it 14-7 Indians with eight seconds to go in the first. 
From that point, the rout was on for East Coweta. The Indians scored 21 points in the second quarter. The first score came with 8:33 to go in the half when, following a muffed punt that East Coweta recovered at the Tigers' 45-yard line, Carlos Ford busted through the middle of the Tigers' defense for a 13-yard score and a 21-7 Indians lead. They extended the lead to 28-7 with 3:50 left in the first half on a Carlos Reid 1-yard run. 
A scoring drive was highlighted by a 45-yard completion from Reid to Justin Crump. Crump would get in the end zone himself on East Coweta's next drive. The Indians drove 90 yards, and Reid hit Crump for a three-yard score with 13 seconds to play in the half, making the score 35-7 at the break. Douglas County tried to 
make it interesting to open the second half as Charles Gadie went 65 yards for a touchdown on the kickoff to cut the lead to 35-13. 
East Coweta, however, quickly answered with a six-play drive that was finished off by Ford’s 1-yard run to make it 42-13 for the Indians with 8:56 to go in the third. Douglas County scored late with a 64-yard run from D.J. Avery with 6:30 left in the game to make it 42-20 East Coweta. 
"We said it all week: ‘There's an elephant in the room and it's Newnan,’" Pardue said. "Now we can focus on Newnan. We have a lot of kids banged up, but you kind of feel like maybe they will get better a little faster because it's such a big game.” 
INDIANS 42, TIGERS 7 
Douglas Co. 7 0 67—20 1st Quarter 
EC- Jeremiah Gemmel 29 run 
(Wyatt Palmer kick), 7:12 
DC- Malik Oliver 8 run (Austin Blair kick), 6:13 
EC- Calvin Kirby 12 run (Palmer kick), 0:08 
2nd Quarter 
EC- Carlos Ford 13 run (Palmer kick), 8:33 
EC- Christian Reid 1 run (Palmer kick), 3:50 
EC- Justin Crump 3-yard pass from Reid (Palmer kick), 0:13 
3rd Quarter 
DC- Charles Gadie 65-yard kick return (kick failed), 11:45 
EC- Ford 1 run (Palmer kick), 8:56 
4th Quarter 
DC- D.J. Avery 64-yard run (Blair kick), 6:30 More
